sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; application is a simple text editor. You can use &app; to create and edit text files. You can use &app; plugins to perform a variety of tasks related to text-editing from within the &app; window.

sect2.title: To Start &app; from the Command Line
sect2.para: To start &app; from the command line, type the following command, then press Return:

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of the gedit main window.

sect2.para: The &app; window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menus on the menubar contain all of the commands you need to work with files in &app;.
The toolbar contains a subset of the commands that you can access from the menubar.
The text window contains the text of the file that you are editing.
The statusbar displays information about current &app; activity and contextual information about the menu items.

sect2.title: To Open a File
sect2.para:
To open a file, choose File Open
to display the Open File dialog. Select the file that you want to open, then click OK. The file is displayed in the &app; window.

You can open multiple files in &app;. The application displays one file at a time in the application window. The application adds a tab for each open file to the window. To display another open file, click on the tab that corresponds to the file. To create a new &app; window for each file that is open, drag the tab corresponding to each file to the desktop. You can also use the Documents menu to move between the open files.

The application also records the paths and file names of the last four files that you edited and displays them as menu items on the File menu. To open one of the last four files, choose for example File 1. /path/filename .

sect2.title: To Open Multiple Files from a Command Line
sect2.para: You can run &app; from a command line and open a single file or multiple files. To open multiple files from a command line, type the following command, then press Return:
When the application starts, the files that you specified are displayed in the &app; window.

sect2.title: To Create a New File
sect2.para: To create a new file, choose File New . The application displays a new file in the &app; window.

sect2.title: To Save a File
sect2.para: You can save files in the following ways:

listitem.para: To save a new file, choose File Save As . Enter a name for the file in the Save As dialog box, then click OK.
To save changes to the current file, choose File Save .
To save all of the files that are currently open in &app;, choose File Save All .

sect2.title: To Edit Text
sect2.para: You can edit the text of a file in the following ways:

listitem.para: Type new text from the keyboard.
Use the Delete key to delete text.
Use the Cut, Copy, Paste, and Clear menu items to edit text.

sect2.para: When you select text with the mouse, &app; automatically copies the selected text to a buffer. You can perform any of the following actions on the selected text:

listitem.para: To delete the selected text from the file and move the selected text to a buffer, choose Edit Cut .
To insert the contents of the buffer at the cursor position, middle-click or choose Edit Paste . You must cut or copy text before you can paste text into the file.
To select all of the text in a file, choose Edit Select All .

sect2.title: To Undo or Redo Edits
sect2.para: To undo an edit, choose Edit Undo . To redo an edit, choose Edit Redo . The number of previous edits that you can undo is determined by the Set limit on undo levels to setting in the tabbed section of the Preferences dialog. By default, there is no limit on the number of edits that you can undo.

sect2.title: To Find Text
sect2.para: To search a file for a string, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Search Find to display the Find dialog.
Type the string that you want to find in the Search for field.
Select one of the following options:

para.guilabel: Search from the beginning of the document

listitem.para: Select the Case sensitive option to only find occurrences of the string that match the case of the text that you type.
Click Find to search the file for the first occurrence of the string. If &app; finds the string, the application moves the cursor to the string, and selects the string.
To find the next occurrence of the string, click Find Next.
To finish the search, click Close.

sect2.title: To Find and Replace Text
sect2.para: To search a file for a string, and replace the string with an alternative string, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Search Replace to display the Replace dialog.
Type the string that you want to find in the Search for field.
Type the string that you want to use to replace the string that you find in the Replace with field.
Select one of the following options:

para.guilabel: Search from the beginning of the document

listitem.para: Select the Case sensitive option to only find occurrences of the string that match the case of the text that you enter.
Click Find to search the file for the first occurrence of the string. If &app; finds the string, the application moves the cursor to the string, and selects the string.
Click on Replace to replace the occurrence of the string with the text that you typed in the Replace with field. Click on Replace All to replace all occurrences of the string.
To find the next occurrence of the string, click Find Next.
To finish the search, click Close.

sect2.title: To Open a File from a URI
sect2.para: To open a file from a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI), perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose File Open From URI to display the Open from URI dialog.
Enter the URI of the file that you want to open.
Click Open.

sect2.title: To Pipe the Output of a Command to a File
sect2.para: You can use &app; to pipe the output of a command to a text file. For example, to pipe the output of an ls command to a text file, type the following command, then press Return:
The output of the ls command is displayed in a new text file in the &app; window.
Alternatively, you can use the Shell Output plugin to pipe command output to the current file. To use the Shell Output plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the Shell Output plugin. See for information about how to load a plugin.
Choose Edit Insert shell output to display the Shell output dialog.
Type the shell command that you want to execute in the Shell command field.
Edit the Working directory field if necessary. By default, the Shell Output plugin executes the command you specify in the current directory.
Click Run. The Shell Output plugin executes the command and inserts the text output into the current file.

sect2.title: To Go to a Specific Line
sect2.para: To go to a specific line in the current file, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Search Goto Line to display the Goto line dialog.
Type the number of the line that you want to move the cursor to in the Line number field.
Click Goto line. The application moves the cursor to the line number that you specify.

sect2.title: To Change the Input Mode
sect2.para: To change the input mode, right-click in the text window, then select Input Methods. The Insert Unicode control character menu item provides character layout options that are useful for working with non-Latin character sets.

sect2.title: To Print a File
sect2.para: You can use &app; to perform the following print operations:

listitem.para: Print a file to a printer.
Print the output of the print command to a file.

sect2.para: If you print to a file, &app; sends the output of the file to a pre-press format file. The most common pre-press formats are PostScript and Portable Document Format (PDF).
To print the current file to a printer or a file, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose File Print to display the Print Document dialog.
To print the file to a printer, perform the following steps:
Select the Printer option.
Verify the default print command displayed to the right of the Printer option and modify if necessary.
To print the file to a pre-press format, perform the following steps:
Select the File option.
Enter a name for the output file in the field to the right of the File check box. The default file name is output.ps.
To specify a different file format, use the Name drop-down list box.
To print all of the pages in the file, select the All option.
To print some of the pages in the file, perform the following steps:
Select the Pages option.
To decide which pages you want to print, click on the Preview button to preview a printed copy of the document.
Enter the number of the first page that you want to print in the Start field.
Enter the number of the last page that you want to print in the End field.
To print the text that is currently selected, select the Selected option.
To preview the pages that you are about to print, click Preview to display the Print Preview Document dialog.
To print your selection, click Print.

sect2.title: To Use the &app; Plugins
sect2.para: A plugin is a supplementary program that enhances the functionality of an application. The &app; plugins enable you to perform a variety of functions related to text editing from within the &app; window. The following table lists the plugins that are available.

entry.para: Displays a dialog that contains an ASCII table. You can use the ASCII table to insert characters into a file.
Compares two files and displays the differences between the files in a new &app; window. This plugin uses the diff program to compare the files.
Opens the log messages associated with CVS commit commands.
Counts the number of lines, words, characters with spaces, characters without spaces, and bytes in the current file. The plugin displays the results in a Word count window.
Provides GNOME developers with a template for writing other &app; plugins.
Inserts the text output of a shell command into a file.
Displays a dialog that contains a list of common tags. You can use the dialog to insert a tag into a file.
Inserts the current date and time into a file.

sect2.title: To Load &app; Plugins
sect2.para:
To load &app; plugins, choose
Tools Plugins manager . The Plugin Manager dialog displays the following information:

listitem.para: A list of the plugins that are available.
A Configure plugin button. You can use this button to open a configuration dialog for some of the plugins.
A brief description of each plugin. To display a description, select the plugin from the list of plugins.
Details about the author of the plugin and the name of the module.

sect2.para: To load a plugin, select the check box next to the name of the plugin. The &app; application adds the plugin to the appropriate &app; menu, as described in the following table.
To remove a plugin, deselect the check box next to the name of the plugin.
To close the Plugin Manager dialog, click Close.

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para: The Preferences dialog contains the following categories:

sect2.title: Editor
sect2.para: The Editor category is subdivided into the following subcategories:

listitem.para: Select this option to use the default system font for the text in the &app; text window.
Default: unselected.
This field displays the font that &app; uses to display text. Click on the button to specify the font type, style, and size to use for text.
Default: Courier Medium 12 point.
Select this option to use the default theme colors in the &app; text window.
Default: selected.
Default: black.
Default: white.
Click on the Selected text color button to display the color selector dialog. Select a color to use to display selected text.
Default: white.
Click on the Selection color button to display the color selector dialog. Select a background color to use to highlight a text selection.
Default: blue.
Use this spin box to specify the width of the space that &app; inserts when you press the Tab key.
Default: 8 characters.
Select this option to never wrap lines. The text that you type is displayed in one line until you press Return.
Select this option to wrap text onto the next line, at a word level, when you reach the text window boundary.
Select this option to wrap text onto the next line, at a character level, when you reach the text window boundary.
Default: Never wrap lines.
Select this option to display lines numbers on the left side of the &app; window.
Default: unselected.

term.guilabel: Create a backup copy of files before saving

listitem.para: Select this option create a backup copy of a file each time you save the file. The backup copy of the file has a .bak extension.
Default: unselected.
Select this option to automatically save the current file at regular intervals. Use the spin box to specify the interval at which you want to save the file.
Default: unselected, 10 minutes.
Select one of the following save options:
Select this option to save files using UTF-8 bit encoding.
Select this option to save files using the current locale. You can set up locales for different input methods.

para.guilabel: Use current locale only if the file already uses it

listitem.para: Select this option to save a file using the current locale if the file was already saved in the current locale.
Default: Always use UTF-8 encoding

term.guilabel: Set limit on undo levels to

listitem.para: Select this option to set a limit on the number of editing actions that you can undo. Use the spin box to specify the maximum number of actions that you can undo.
Default: selected, 25 actions.

sect2.title: Print
sect2.para: The Print category is subdivided into the following subcategory:

listitem.para: Select this option to include a header on each page that you print. You can not configure the header.
Default: selected.
Select this option to automatically wrap text at a character level when you print a file. The application counts wrapped lines as one line for line numbering purposes.
Default: selected.
Select this option to include line numbers when you print a file. Use the spin box to specify how often to print the line numbers, for example every 5 lines, every 10 lines, and so on.
Default: unselected, 1 line.

sect2.title: User Interface
sect2.para: The User Interface category is subdivided into the following subcategories:

listitem.para: Select one of the following options to determine whether &app; displays the toolbar:
Select this option to display the toolbar in the &app; window.
Select this option to hide the toolbar from the &app; window.
Default: Show.
Select one of the following options to determine how &app; displays the buttons on the toolbar:
Select this option to set the format and functionality of the toolbar to comply with the GNOME desktop settings. To change the GNOME desktop settings for toolbars, go to the GNOME Control Center.
Select this option to display icons only on the toolbar buttons.
Select this option to display icons and text on the toolbar buttons.
Default: According to system settings.
Select this option to display tooltips about the buttons on the toolbar.
Default: selected.
Select one of the following options to determine whether &app; displays the statusbar at the botton of the &app; window:
Select this option to display the statusbar in the &app; window.
Select this option to hide the statusbar from the &app; window.
Default: Show.
Select this option to display the line number and column number where the cursor is located.
Default: unselected.
Select this option to display the editing mode. If the editor is in insert mode, the statusbar contains the word INS. If the editor is in overwrite mode, the statusbar contains the word OVR.
Default: unselected.
